data.MARCRELATORS.extended

Relators [MARC]. Values and definitions taken from http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators.
Module
MEI.shared
Used by
These other Data Types reference data.MARCRELATORS.extended
data.RELATORSDatatypes for values to specify roles.
Suggested Values
actA performer contributing to an expression of a work by acting as a cast member or player in a musical or dramatic presentation, etc. [MARC]
ardA person responsible for controlling the development of the artistic style of an entire production, including the choice of works to be presented and selection of senior production staff. [MARC]
artA person, family, or organization responsible for creating a work by conceiving, and implementing, an original graphic design, drawing, painting, etc. For book illustrators, prefer Illustrator. [MARC]
ausAn author of a screenplay, script, or scene. [MARC]
chrA person responsible for creating or contributing to a work of movement. [MARC]
cndA performer contributing to a musical resource by leading a performing group (orchestra, chorus, opera, etc.) in a musical or dramatic presentation. [MARC]
crpA person or organization who was either the writer or recipient of a letter or other communication. [MARC]
cstA person, family, or organization that designs the costumes for a moving image production or for a musical or dramatic presentation or entertainment. [MARC]
drtA person responsible for the general management and supervision of a filmed performance, a radio or television program, etc. [MARC]
egrA person or organization who cuts letters, figures, etc. on a surface, such as a wooden or metal plate used for printing. [MARC]
flmA person who, following the script and in creative cooperation with the Director, selects, arranges, and assembles the filmed material, controls the synchronization of picture and sound, and participates in other post-production tasks such as sound mixing and visual effects processing. Today, picture editing is often performed digitally. [MARC]
fmdA director responsible for the general management and supervision of a filmed performance. [MARC]
fmpA producer responsible for most of the business aspects of a film. [MARC]
itrA performer contributing to a resource by playing a musical instrument. [MARC]
mcpA person who transcribes or copies musical notation. [MARC]
musA person or organization who performs music or contributes to the musical content of a work when it is not possible or desirable to identify the function more precisely. [MARC]
msdA person who coordinates the activities of the composer, the sound editor, and sound mixers for a moving image production or for a musical or dramatic presentation or entertainment. [MARC]
pdrA person or organization with primary responsibility for all essential aspects of a project, has overall responsibility for managing projects, or provides overall direction to a project manager. [MARC]
pmnA person responsible for all technical and business matters in a production. [MARC]
prnAn organization that is responsible for financial, technical, and organizational management of a production for stage, screen, audio recording, television, webcast, etc. [MARC]
proA person, family, or organization responsible for most of the business aspects of a production for screen, audio recording, television, webcast, etc. The producer is generally responsible for fund raising, managing the production, hiring key personnel, arranging for distributors, etc. [MARC]
rceA person contributing to a resource by supervising the technical aspects of a sound or video recording session. [MARC]
scrA person who is an amanuensis and for a writer of manuscripts proper. For a person who makes pen-facsimiles, use facsimilist. [MARC]
sngA performer contributing to a resource by using his/her/their voice, with or without instrumental accompaniment, to produce music. A singer's performance may or may not include actual words. [MARC]
stdA person who translates the rough sketches of the art director into actual architectural structures for a theatrical presentatio.n, entertainment, motion picture, etc. Set designers draw the detailed guides and specifications for building the set. [MARC]
trcA person, family, or organization contributing to a resource by changing it from one system of notation to another. For a work transcribed for a different instrument or performing group, see arranger [arr]. For makers of pen-facsimiles, use facsimilist. [MARC]
trlA person or organization who renders a text from one language into another, or from an older form of a language into the modern form. [MARC]
Declaration

.</desc>

]</desc>
</valItem>
<valItem ident="pro">
<gloss versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">producer</gloss>
<desc versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">A person, family, or organization responsible for most of the business aspects of a production for screen, audio recording, television, webcast, etc. The producer is generally responsible for fund raising, managing the production, hiring key personnel, arranging for distributors, etc. [
<ref target="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/pro.html">MARC</ref>
]</desc>
</valItem>
<valItem ident="rce">
<gloss versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">recording engineer</gloss>
<desc versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">A person contributing to a resource by supervising the technical aspects of a sound or video recording session. [

]</desc>
</valItem>
<valItem ident="scr">
<gloss versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">scribe</gloss>
<desc versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">A person who is an amanuensis and for a writer of manuscripts proper. For a person who makes pen-facsimiles, use facsimilist. [
<ref target="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/scr.html">MARC</ref>
]</desc>
</valItem>
<valItem ident="sng">
<gloss versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">singer</gloss>
<desc versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">A performer contributing to a resource by using his/her/their voice, with or without instrumental accompaniment, to produce music. A singer's performance may or may not include actual words. [
<ref target="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/sng.html">MARC</ref>
]</desc>
</valItem>
<valItem ident="std">
<gloss versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">set designer</gloss>
<desc versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">A person who translates the rough sketches of the art director into actual architectural structures for a theatrical presentatio.n, entertainment, motion picture, etc. Set designers draw the detailed guides and specifications for building the set. [
<ref target="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/std.html">MARC</ref>
]</desc>
</valItem>
<valItem ident="trc">
<gloss versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">transcriber</gloss>
<desc versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">A person, family, or organization contributing to a resource by changing it from one system of notation to another. For a work transcribed for a different instrument or performing group, see arranger [arr]. For makers of pen-facsimiles, use facsimilist. [
<ref target="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/trc.html">MARC</ref>
]</desc>
</valItem>
<valItem ident="trl">
<gloss versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">translator</gloss>
<desc versionDate="2025-05-25" xml:lang="en">A person or organization who renders a text from one language into another, or from an older form of a language into the modern form. [
<ref target="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/trl.html">MARC</ref>
]</desc>
</valItem>
